Title: Dancers Charles "Honi" Coles, Charles "Cholly" Atkins, Mae Johnson, Alyce Key, and Pete Nugent, Los Angeles, 1940s
Description.note: All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.|~|The man at the far right of the photo was identified by Mr. Gordon as Langston Hughes; however, there is a handwritten caption identifying him as Peter Nugent Deacon(?).|~|At table, left to right: Charles "Cholly" Atkins, Charles "Hone" Coles, Mae Johnson, unidentified woman, and Pete Nugent. Alyce Key is standing behind the couple at the piano, with a man's hand resting on her shoulder. Atkins and Coles, preeminent tap dancers, performed together for nineteen years, starting in 1940. Atkins was an expert wing dancer, while Coles's specialty was precision.
Summary: Charles "Honi" Coles was an American actor and tap dancer known for his extraordinary elegance and technical precision. He learned to dance on the streets of Philadelphia and went on to a career on stage in vaudeville and the concert world, in film, and on television. He served as president of the Negro Actors Guild and was at the forefront of the tap revival starting in the early 1970s. He brought tap to the world of concert dance with his performance in the Joffrey Ballet production of Agnes De Mille's "Conversations on the Dance", in 1978. In 1983 he received the Tony Award, Fred Astaire Award, and Drama Desk Award for best featured actor and dancer in a musical for the Broadway hit, My One and Only.|~|Gary Lambert “Pete” Nugent was a preeminent tap dancer in the class act tradition. In the 1930s he was a member of the act of “Pete, Peaches and Duke,” performing in venues such as the Cotton Club. After that he had a solo act “Public Tapper, Number One”.  During World War II he spent his military service touring in Irving Berlin’s show This is the Army. From about 1947 to about 1965, he ran for political office at the city and State levels several times. Affiliated with the Republican Party starting in 1956, he returned to the Democratic Party in 1966.  As of 1966, he was a Los Angeles County public defender. In 1987 he was a judge pro tempore in the Inglewood Municipal Court.
